repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
* Implemented as simple type wrapper class since it's really just a rename when used in Python.
* Allow "cython.pointer[xyz]" and "cython.array[xyz]" in Python code.
* Add "p_const_XYZ" type alias names to simplify the usage.
* Generate type aliases in "Shadow.pyi".

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5728
Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5071

comment_data.body:
This probably needs a test for `const[pointer[const[int]]]` which I believe should be valid. 

I suspect it might pass already but I think it's worth having a test for.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3902,8 +3902,34 @@ def analyse_target_declaration(self, env):
         pass
 
     def analyse_as_type(self, env):
+        modifier = self.base.as_cython_attribute()
+        if modifier is not None and modifier in ('const', 'volatile'):
+            # const[base_type] or volatile[base_type]
+            is_const = modifier == 'const'
+            is_volatile = not is_const
+            base_type = self.index.analyse_as_type(env)
+            if base_type is None:
+                error(self.base.pos, f"invalid use of '{modifier}', argument is not a type")
+                return None
+            elif base_type.is_cv_qualified:

comment_data.body: This is supported only by Python 3.12+. Should not we support older python versions?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,6 +152,9 @@ def typeof(__obj: object) -> str: ...
 
 def address(__obj: object) -> PointerType: ...
 
+type const[T] = Annotated[T, "cython.const"]

comment_data.body: This file should not be created somewhere else since it is not User Facing script? E.g. in `Tools`?

Yeah - it does look like there's an expectation for pyi files to be backwards compatible.

> They should be parseable (e.g., with ast.parse()) in all Python versions that are supported by the implementation and that are still supported by the CPython project. For example, defining a type alias using the type keyword is only accepted by the Python parser in Python 3.12 and later, so stubs supporting Python 3.11 or earlier versions should not use this syntax

https://typing.readthedocs.io/en/latest/spec/distributing.html#syntax
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,6 +152,9 @@ def typeof(__obj: object) -> str: ...
 
 def address(__obj: object) -> PointerType: ...
 
+type const[T] = Annotated[T, "cython.const"]

comment_data.body: In this list are missing `const_*` types and `volatile_*` types (e.g. `const_bint` and `volatile_bint`). If I understand PR correctly, they should be supported by PR.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -280,3 +255,225 @@ class typedef(CythonType, Generic[_T]):
     def __call__(self, *arg: Any) -> _T: ...
     def __repr__(self) -> str: ...
     __getitem__ = index_type
+
+
+##### START: GENERATED LIST OF GENERATED TYPES #####
+# Generated by "bin/cython-generate-shadow-pyi.py" on 2024-09-17 20:41:27.411413
+
+p_const_bint = PointerType[const[bint]]

comment_data.body:
> missing `const_*` types and `volatile_*` types

I had left them out because `const` by itself isn't very useful in Cython. You can't use it for local variables, for example. But these might still be used when defining arguments of `cdef` functions. I'll add them.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -280,3 +255,225 @@ class typedef(CythonType, Generic[_T]):
     def __call__(self, *arg: Any) -> _T: ...
     def __repr__(self) -> str: ...
     __getitem__ = index_type
+
+
+##### START: GENERATED LIST OF GENERATED TYPES #####
+# Generated by "bin/cython-generate-shadow-pyi.py" on 2024-09-17 20:41:27.411413
+
+p_const_bint = PointerType[const[bint]]

comment_data.body: Right. There's also the Lexicon.py generator tool which I've now moved to "Tools/" as well.

It's currently `PointerType[cython.int]` because `pointer()` is a function and doesn't allow item access. Should we change `pointer` into a callable type class? That would avoid having two names for essentially the same thing.

I tried `const[PointerType[const[int]]]` and that's not currently accepted by this PR because Cython's type analysis doesn't know about `PointerType` yet. So now would be the time to fix the name.

comment_data.body: I changed the `type` statements to `: TypeAlias` declarations.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,6 +152,9 @@ def typeof(__obj: object) -> str: ...

+type const[T] = Annotated[T, "cython.const"]

commit.message:
Support "cython.const[base_type]" and "cython.volatile[base_type]" in Python code.

* Implemented as "cython.typedef" subclass since it's really just a rename when used in Python.
* Allow "cython.PointerType[xyz]" and "cython.ArrayType[xyz]" in Python code.
* Add "p_const_XYZ" type alias names to simplify the usage.
* Generate type aliases in "Shadow.pyi".

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5728
Include 'const_xyz' types, not only const pointers.
Move internal code generation tools from "bin/" (which should be user installable) to "Tools/" (which is not publicly used).
Change "pointer" and "array" types into classes to allow "pointer[int]" directly.
Let mypy validate the pointer type annotations and fix some missing bits in Shadow.pyi.

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.7.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Support "cython.const[base_type]" and "cython.volatile[base_type]" in Python code
